messages.content:
You are a professional academic reference prediction expert. Your task is to predict the most likely references for a given academic paper based on its title, abstract, and retrieved relevant papers.

RETRIEVER INTERFACE:
- Input: paper title + abstract
- Output: {top_r} retrieved papers with title and abstract
- Format: List of dictionaries with 'title' and 'abstract' fields

REQUIREMENTS:
1. Analyze the paper's title and abstract to understand its research area and focus
2. Consider the retrieved papers as potential references (when available)
3. Generate a list of predicted reference titles that would be most relevant and likely to be cited
4. Provide reasoning for each prediction to prevent hallucination
5. Output format: JSON object with "titles" array and "reasoning" string
6. Generate exactly 55 most relevant reference titles (this should be at least 40 to cover all evaluation metrics)
7. Ensure titles are realistic and appropriate for the research area
8. Consider citation patterns in the field
9. CRITICAL: Each title must be unique - never repeat the same title multiple times

EXAMPLE:
Input:
Title: "Question Type Classification Methods Comparison"
Abstract: "The paper presents a comparative study of state-of-the-art approaches for question classification task: Logistic Regression, Convolutional Neural Networks (CNN), Long Short-Term Memory Network (LSTM) and Quasi-Recurrent Neural Networks (QRNN). All models use pre-trained GLoVe word embeddings and trained on human-labeled data. The best accuracy is achieved using CNN model with five convolutional layers and various kernel sizes stacked in parallel, followed by one fully connected layer. The model reached 90.7% accuracy on TREC 10 test set."

Retrieved papers ({top_r}):
1. Title: Convolutional Neural Networks for Sentence Classification
   Abstract: We report on a series of experiments with convolutional neural networks trained on top of pre-trained word vectors for sentence-level classification tasks.

2. Title: Glove: Global vectors for word representation
   Abstract: We present a new global log-bilinear regression model that combines the advantages of the two major model families in the literature.

Output:
{
  "titles": [
    "Convolutional Neural Networks for Sentence Classification",
    "Glove: Global vectors for word representation",
    "Quasi-Recurrent Neural Networks",
    "A Comparative Study of Neural Network Models for Sentence Classification",
    "Deep lstm based feature mapping for query classification"
  ],
  "reasoning": "Based on the paper's focus on question classification using neural networks, I predict these references because: 1) CNN paper is directly relevant to the convolutional approach used; 2) GloVe embeddings are mentioned as pre-trained features; 3) QRNN is one of the compared methods; 4) Comparative study papers are common in this field; 5) LSTM-based query classification is closely related to question classification. Additional references cover related neural network architectures, NLP applications, deep learning methodologies, optimization techniques, and advanced neural network methods that would be relevant for this research area."
}

Return JSON object only.

Paper Title: Small Covers for Near-Zero Sets of Polynomials and Learning Latent Variable Models1footnote 11footnote 1An extended abstract of this work appears in the proceedings of the 61st Annual IEEE Symposium on Foundations of Computer Science (FOCS 2020).

Paper Abstract: Abstract Let V𝑉V be any vector space of multivariate degree-d𝑑d homogeneous polynomials with co-dimension at most k𝑘k, and S𝑆S be the set of points where all polynomials in V𝑉V nearly vanish. We establish a qualitatively optimal upper bound on the size of ϵitalic-ϵ\epsilon-covers for S𝑆S, in the ℓ2subscriptℓ2\ell_{2}-norm. Roughly speaking, we show that there exists an ϵitalic-ϵ\epsilon-cover for S𝑆S of cardinality M=(k/ϵ)Od​(k1/d)𝑀superscript𝑘italic-ϵsubscript𝑂𝑑superscript𝑘1𝑑M=(k/\epsilon)^{O_{d}(k^{1/d})}. Our result is constructive yielding an algorithm to compute such an ϵitalic-ϵ\epsilon-cover that runs in time poly​(M)poly𝑀\mathrm{poly}(M). Building on our structural result, we obtain significantly improved learning algorithms for several fundamental high-dimensional probabilistic models with hidden variables. These include density and parameter estimation for k𝑘k-mixtures of spherical Gaussians (with known common covariance), PAC learning one-hidden-layer ReLU networks with k𝑘k hidden units (under the Gaussian distribution), density and parameter estimation for k𝑘k-mixtures of linear regressions (with Gaussian covariates), and parameter estimation for k𝑘k-mixtures of hyperplanes. Our algorithms run in time quasi-polynomial in the parameter k𝑘k. Previous algorithms for these problems had running times exponential in kΩ​(1)superscript𝑘Ω1k^{\Omega(1)}. At a high-level our algorithms for all these learning problems work as follows: By computing the low-degree moments of the hidden parameters, we are able to find a vector space of polynomials that nearly vanish on the unknown parameters. Our structural result allows us to compute a quasi-polynomial sized cover for the set of hidden parameters, which we exploit in our learning algorithms.

{retrieved_text}

Generate exactly 55 most likely reference titles for this paper. Focus on papers that are directly related to the research topic, provide foundational background, present similar methodologies, or address related problems.

CRITICAL: Each title must appear exactly once. Do not repeat any title.

IMPORTANT: You must respond with ONLY valid JSON in this exact format:
{
    "titles": [
        "Reference Title 1",
        "Reference Title 2",
        "Reference Title 3",
        "Reference Title 4",
        "Reference Title 55"
    ],
    "reasoning": "Explain why you chose these specific references based on the paper's title, abstract, and retrieved papers. This helps prevent hallucination and ensures relevance."
}

Do not include any text before or after the JSON. Do not include authors, venues, or years - only the paper titles. The reasoning field is required to explain your prediction logic.

{
    "titles": [
        "The more, the merrier: the blessing of dimensionality for learning large gaussian mixtures",
        "Nearly tight sample complexity bounds for learning mixtures of gaussians via sample compression schemes",
        "Sample-optimal density estimation in nearly-linear time",
        "Learning mixtures of arbitrary Gaussians",
        "On spectral learning of mixtures of distributions",
        "Smoothed analysis of tensor decompositions",
        "Learning two layer rectified neural networks in polynomial time",
        "Etude des coefficients fourier des fonctiones de lp​(g)superscript𝑙𝑝𝑔l^{p}(g)",
        "Sparse solutions to nonnegative linear systems and applications",
        "Isotropic PCA and Affine-Invariant Clustering",
        "Learning mixtures of structured distributions over discrete domains",
        "Efficient density estimation via piecewise polynomial approximation",
        "Learning mixtures of linear regressions in subexponential time via fourier moments",
        "Distributional and Lqsuperscript𝐿𝑞L^{q} norm inequalities for polynomials over convex bodies in Rnsuperscript𝑅𝑛R^{n}",
        "Learning mixtures of Gaussians",
        "Mixtures of linear regressions",
        "Toward deeper understanding of neural networks: The power of initialization and a dual view on expressivity",
        "Faster and sample near-optimal algorithms for proper learning mixtures of Gaussians",
        "Robust estimators in high dimensions without the computational intractability",
        "Algorithms and SQ lower bounds for PAC learning one-hidden-layer relu networks",
        "Statistical query lower bounds for robust estimation of high-dimensional Gaussians and Gaussian mixtures",
        "List-decodable robust mean estimation and learning mixtures of spherical Gaussians",
        "Efficient algorithms and lower bounds for robust linear regression",
        "PAC learning mixtures of Gaussians with no separation assumption",
        "Learning mixtures of gaussians in high dimensions",
        "Learning neural networks with two nonlinear layers in polynomial time",
        "Reliably learning the relu in polynomial time",
        "Learning two-layer neural networks with symmetric inputs",
        "Learning one-hidden-layer neural networks with landscape design",
        "Logarithmic Sobolev inequalities",
        "Learning mixtures of spherical gaussians: moment methods and spectral decompositions",
        "Mixture models, robustness, and sum of squares proofs",
        "Tight bounds for learning a mixture of two gaussians",
        "Hierarchical mixtures of experts and the EM algorithm",
        "Beating the perils of non-convexity: Guaranteed training of neural networks using tensor methods",
        "EM converges for a mixture of many linear regressions",
        "Talk at stoc’17 workshop on new challenges in machine learning – robustness and nonconvexity",
        "Outlier-robust moment-estimation via sum-of-squares",
        "The spectral method for general mixture models",
        "Learning mixtures of linear regressions with nearly optimal complexity",
        "Robust and proper learning for mixtures of gaussians via systems of polynomial inequalities",
        "The computational complexity of training relu(s)",
        "Settling the polynomial learnability of mixtures of Gaussians",
        "Analysis of Boolean Functions",
        "Contribution to the mathematical theory of evolution",
        "Subspace clustering for high dimensional data: a review",
        "On learning mixtures of well-separated gaussians",
        "Provable tensor methods for learning mixtures of generalized linear models",
        "Near-optimal-sample estimators for spherical Gaussian mixtures",
        "Subspace clustering",
        "A spectral algorithm for learning mixtures of distributions",
        "Gradient descent for one-hidden-layer neural networks: Polynomial convergence and SQ lower bounds",
        "Mixed linear regression with multiple components",
        "L1-regularized neural networks are improperly learnable in polynomial time",
        "Recovery guarantees for one-hidden-layer neural networks"
    ],
    "reasoning": "Selected these 55 references because they represent foundational work and recent advances in Small Covers for Near-Zero Sets of Polynomials and Learning Latent Variable Models1footnote 11footnote 1An extended abstract of this work appears in the proceedings of the 61st Annual IEEE Symposium on Foundations of Computer Science (FOCS 2020)., providing essential background knowledge and methodological foundations relevant to this research."
}
